title: ECMO Cart
content:
ECMO Cart Requirements

An ECMO cart is used for cannulation, reconfiguration, management of various complications, and decannulation in any non-operating room setting. Review the requirements then select the equipment according to your ECMO needs.
  • The items included MUST be immediately available for the cannulating team.
  • The cart should be kept in a dedicated location when not in use.
  • The items in the cart and on top of the cart MUST be maintained. This means they MUST be checked for content and expiration dates, and refilled with used items, as per center policy.

title: Anticoagulation with Intravenous Unfractionated Heparin (UFH)
content: Use this checklist to guide the initiation and maintenance of intravenous unfractionated heparin (UFH) anticoagulation following ECMO cannulation.
keywords: Anticoagulation; Heparin; Unfractionated Heparin; UFH; Anticoagulants; ECMO Cannulation; Intravenous; AntiXa; aPTT; Coagulation

items.label: ECMO Cannulation
UFH IV Bolus: 50-100 IU/kg
Consider dose according to coagulation status and bleeding risk.
Continuous Anticoagulation
Starting dose: 10-15 IU/kg /h using actual body weight (use adjusted body weight if BMI â‰¥ 40 kg/m<sup class="math-sup">2</sup>).
Maintenance dose will be determined based on the anticoagulation target for (according to local protocol, if available, coagulation status and bleeding risk)*:
Low: AntiXa 0.2-0.3 IU/mL and/or aPTT: 40-55s; ratio 1.2-1.6;
Moderate: AntiXa 0.3-0.5 IU/mL and/or aPTT: 50-70s; ratio 1.5-2;
High: AntiXa 0.5-0.7 IU/mL and/or aPTT: 60-80s; ratio 1.8-2.4.
Monitor anticoagulation parameters at least twice daily and after four hours after any dose adjustment.
Below target: increase UFH dose 10-20%^, check anticoagulation parameter after four hours.
Above target: decrease UFH dose 10-20%^, check anticoagulation parameter after four hours.
Discrepancy between aPTT and AntiXa: Refer to the Discrepancy between aPTT and AntiXa with UFH Table under Anticoagulants.
Daily assessment for Bleeding and Thromboembolism and HIT
Refer to Management of bleeding
Clotting in circuit
Membrane exchange
Drop in platelet count

Note: * target ranges of aPTT are dependent on reagent and therefore may vary between institutions; ^intensity of dose reduction will be dependent on the magnitude of AntiXa or aPTT concentration above the target range

title: Circuit Component Changes
content: Use this checklist if you need to replace a component within an ECMO circuit. This checklist should be adapted to align with institutional policies, specific patient conditions, and  available resources.

items.label: Identify the need for circuit component replacement
To proceed with whole circuit replacement, all three checks are required. Otherwise, do NOT proceed with whole circuit replacement.
Note: ELSO does NOT recommend non-urgent replacement of a circuit or circuit component.
Dysfunctional circuit component: (at least 1 check)
Component thrombosis (minor membrane lung (ML) clotting not severely impacting with its function excluded).
Refer to Membrane Lung Failure.
Broken component
No weaning potential
Replacement of the whole circuit is not indicated
Refer to Whole Circuit Replacement.
OR
Need to switch to different configurations (e.g., VAV to VV or VA, VV-V to VV or VV to  VV-V, etc.)
Alert/activate the ECLS Team
Notify the ICU teams
1 experienced intensivist or other ECMO-trained physician
1 experienced ICU nurse to support the patient if as needed
1 experienced ICU nurse to support the patient if as needed
1 assisting ECMO specialist/perfusionist, if possible
If this is an elective procedure, consider having a short pre-procedure briefing.
Prepare the Essential Equipment
Refresh the team on techniques for air-free circuit connections.
Sterile consumables for "sterile operator"
Sterile tubing scissors
4 sterile tubing clamps
2 back-up sterile tubing clamps
1 sterile bowl
1 L of crystalloid solution
New component (CP, ML, tubing piece, connector)
2 straight connectors adapted to circuit tubing size
Disinfecting solution and/or applicators for tubings preparation (per institutional policy)
Devices for air-free connection
Large cone syringes OR
Pigtail/infusion bag OR
14G IV line
Prepare the Patient
Consider the following:
Supine the patient in same position as for initiation
If the patient is awake:
Inform him/her and/or their surrogate about the need for replacement, the procedure and potential associated risks (consent)
Consider sedation, if deemed necessary
Increase mechanical ventilation settings as ready to interrupt extracorporeal blood flow on VV ECMO, V-AV ECMO, VP ECMO
Increase inotropic/vasopressor support as ready to interrupt extracorporeal blood flow on VA ECMO, V-AV ECMO, VP ECMO
Be ready for PRBC transfusion if required
Be ready to perform CPR/ACLS if/as required in case of emergency
If the patient isn't on mechanical ventilation, be ready to manage airways in case of emergency
Check the coagulation profile and increase anticoagulant dosing if deemed necessary
Proceed with Replacement
Support the patient if/as needed throughout the procedure.
If cardiac arrest occurs during the procedure and EBF can be promptly restarted, carefully consider if adrenaline  administration is advisable or could be delayed.
Centrifugal Pump Replacement
Disinfect the portion of tubing which is going to be cut on both sides of the old centrifugal pump (CP).
Allow the solution to act for enough time according to the solution being used.
Clamp the tubing exiting CP.
Go to 0 RPMs and notify the team of the STOP FLOW.
Clamp the drainage tubing close to CP.
Turn OFF the Sweep Gas Flow (SGF).
Place two additional clamps approximately 15cm (6 inches) apart from the previous to isolate the CP from the circuit. If needed, temporarily remove the flowmeter.
Cut the tubings on both sides between the two clamps.
Remove the old centrifugal pump from the motor.
Connect the outflow of the new pump to the circuit.
De-air the new centrifugal pump through the inlet port.
Connect the inlet of the CP to the drainage tubing using an air-free technique. If previously removed, reposition and 0 the flowmeter.
Insert the CP into the motor. Check that there are no kinks or traction in the tubings on both sides.
Remove clamp on the drainage tubing.
Restart the pump.
As minimum RPMs are reached to prevent backflow, remove last clamp.
Refer to the Pump specifications.
Resume the previous RPMs settings if there are no signs of a return obstruction.
Go to Return Obstruction checklist.
Resume previous Sweep Gas Flow settings.
Notify the team of replacement completion.
If using a bubble sensor, and it is alarming for the presence of air before the membrane lung, consider removing through the de-airing port of the ML, without stopping the extracorporeal blood flow.
Refer to Air in Circuit for more information.
Membrane Lung Replacement
Remove Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit lines from the old membrane lung (ML).
Disinfect the portion of tubing which is going to be cut on both sides of the old ML.
Allow the disinfection solution to act for enough time according to the solution being used.
Clamp the tubing exiting the ML.
Go to 0 RPMs and notify the team of the STOP FLOW.
Clamp tubing entering the old ML.
Turn OFF Sweep Gas Flow (SFG) and disconnect the gas line.
Place two additional clamps approximately 15 cm (six inches) apart from the previous to isolate the ML from the circuit.
If needed, temporarily remove the flowmeter.
Cut the tubing on both sides between the two clamps.
Remove the old ML from the holder.
Connect the outflow of the new pump to the circuit.
De-air the new centrifugal pump through the inlet port.
Connect the inlet of the CP to the drainage tubing using the air free technique (if previously removed reposition and 0 the flowmeter).
Insert the CP into the motor. Check for no kinks or traction in the tubings on both sides.
Remove clamp on drainage tubing.
Restart the pump at minimum RPMs reached to prevent backflow.
Depending on IFUs - Refer to the Pump specifications.
Remove the last clamp.
Resume previous RPMs settings, if there are no signs of a return obstruction.
Refer to Return Obstruction for more information.
Resume previous SGF settings.
Notify the team of procedure completion.
If using a bubble sensor, and it is alarming for the presence of air before the membrane lung, consider removing through the de-airing port of the ML, without stopping the extracorporeal blood flow.
Refer to Air in Circuit for more information.
Tubing/Connector Replacement
Disinfect the portion of tubing which is going to be cut.
Allow the disinfection solution to act for enough time according to the solution which has been used.
Clamp the tubing exiting the ML.
Go to 0 RPMs notifying to the team the STOP FLOW.
Clamp tubing entering the old ML.
Turn OFF SGF.
Place two additional clamps to isolate the portion which is going to be cut (three clamps if Y connector  included).
Cut the tubing between the two clamps.
Insert a straight or Y connector as needed in one of the tubing and connect the other/s portion using a wet-wet technique.
If a Y connector is used, connect to the Y connector a new piece of tubing, deair using a cone syringe and connect to the new cannula once all connections are ready.
Remove clamp on drainage tubing.
Restart the pump at minimum RPMs reached to prevent backflow.
Depending on IFUs - Refer to the Pump specifications.
Remove the last clamp.
Resume previous RPMs settings if there are no signs of a return obstruction.
Refer to Return Obstruction.
Resume previous SGF settings.
Notify the team of procedure completion.
Post-Replacement Management
Check all connections for tightness and integrity. Zip tie connections.
Closely monitor the patient for signs of complications.
Adjust ECMO settings as needed, considering improved function of the component, particularly if the ML has been changed.
Perform a full circuit assessment before leaving the patient.
Refer to Circuit Monitoring for additional information.
If the component change was due to an unexpected/unexplained malfunction, inform the manufacturer.
If the old components do not need to be returned to the manufacturer, dispose of them according to hospital protocol. Otherwise, store according to hospital protocol.
Document the procedure in the patient's chart, including:
Reason for replacement
Time of the procedure
Component/connectors lot numbers
Complications encountered
If any, operators
Report the procedure in the ELSO registry.
Suggested Readings

Brogan, T. V., Lequier, L., Lorusso, R., MacLaren, G., & Peek, G. (2023). Extracorporeal life support: The ELSO Red Book (6th ed.). Chapters 4 and 7 , Extracorporeal Life Support Organization. https://www.elso.org/publications.aspx.

Gajkowski EF, Herrera G, Hatton L, Velia Antonini M, Vercaemst L, Cooley E. ELSO Guidelines for Adult and Pediatric Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation Circuits ASAIO J. 2022;68(2):133-152. doi:10.1097/MAT.0000000000001630

title: Coming Off ECMO Emergently
keywords: ECMO; EMERGENTLY; COMING OFF; COMING OFF ECMO EMERGENTLY; TROUBLESHOOTING; MANAGEMENT; ECMO MANAGEMENT

items.label: You suspect the need for coming off emergently
Call for help
Alert and/or activate the ECLS and the ICU teams
Identify the need for coming off emergently
If at least one of the following is true:
Massive air entrance
Refer to Air in Circuit
Accidental decannulation
Go to Accidental Decannulation
Acute circuit thrombosis
Go to No Flow
Major circuit disruption
Go to Air in Circuit
And if weaning is deemed feasible OR no other management option is feasible for any reason, proceed to Coming Off ECMOâ€”Cannulas.
Coming Off ECMOâ€”Cannulas
Coming off Emergently:
Clamp the return tubing to interrupt blood flow
Reduce RPM and SGF to 0
Clamp the drainage tubing
If the cannulas are not functional or no longer required:
Proceed to decannulation
Consider surgical repair or hemostatic devices for arterial cannulas
Use mattress store in the skin for venous cannulas. Compression is not necessary unless there is formation.
If cutdown with ligation into the vessel, it will need surgical decannulation.
If one or more cannulas are still functional or required (also to be used as introducers for alternative cannula)
If coming off due to temporary loss of vascular access due to accidental decannulation, rupture or thrombosis of one cannula, consider:
Clamp the cannula(s) that are still required
Separate the circuit from the cannulas
Flush and clamp the cannulas which are still required
Proceed to Coming Off ECMOâ€”Circuit.
Coming Off ECMOâ€”Circuit
If the circuit is still required:
AND/OR
If the need for coming off is due to temporary loss of vascular access as a result of accidental decannulation, rupture or thrombosis of one cannula, in a scenario of resources constraint:
Keep the circuit functional by recirculating over a bridge OR keep the circuit functional by connecting drainage and return tubing to create a loop.
Flush and clamp the cannula still on site.
If the circuit is NOT functional OR no longer required:
Dispose of the circuit and the cannulas according to hospital protocol.
Clean the ECMO machine according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Proceed to Post-Coming Off Management.
Post-Coming Off and Ongoing Management
Optimize conventional respiratory and/or circulatory support as needed.
Consider post-decannulation screening of the cannulated vessels for complications and treat accordingly.
Consider surgical repair if the arterial vessel is involved.
If decannulation was associated with prolonged cardiac arrest, implement post-resuscitation care and implement as per guidelines.
Strictly monitor the patient.
Document the procedure in the patient's chart and include the reason for coming off and timing off.
Report the procedure in the ELSO registry.

title: Coming Off ECMO
content: Use this checklist to guide the determination of death in patients on ECMO. These checklists may be adapted as necessary to meet local legal, regulatory, and/or institutional policy. Consider a low threshold for additional imaging to demonstrate the absence of cerebral blood flow.
keywords: Diagnose; Death; Neurological; Circulatory

items.label: Neurological Criteria for Determination of Death for Adults
Ensure that the patient has a systolic blood pressure â‰¥ 90-100 mmHg.
OR, if there is no/low pulsatility, use a mean arterial pressure â‰¥ 60 mmHg
Increase inotropes or extracorporeal blood flow as needed.
Ensure that the patientâ€™s core temperature is â‰¥ 36CÂ°.
Optimize the Heater Unit and/or Heater-Cooler Unit temperature as needed.
Ensure acid-base, metabolic, and endocrine homeostasis.
If not feasible, consider performing an ancillary test.
Possible ancillary tests include:
Cerebral angiography
Cerebral angio-CT
Transcranial doppler (TCD) adapted to to the age of the patient and to ECMO configuration
Exclude the influence of anesthetics, sedatives and neuromuscular blocking agents.
If needed, consider measuring plasmatic or urinary concentrations.
If highly lipophilic/protein bound medications have been used AND circuit sequestration cannot be excluded, consider increasing the length of the therapeutic window.
Visit Medications for additional information

Before performing the apnea test, maximize oxygenation both through mechanical ventilation and extracorporeal support, increasing both fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) and fraction of oxygen in the sweep gas flow (FsO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) to 100%.
Decrease sweep gas flow using a stepwise approach titrated on end-tidal CO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> to a minimum of 500/1000 mL (for adults).
Maintain extracorporeal blood flow.
Maintain continuous airway pressure to avoid derecruitment, particularly if the patient is a  potential lung donor.
Observe the patient for evidence of breaths. If the patient is breathing, abort the test immediately.
If hemodynamic instability occurs during the apnea test on VA ECMO, consider increasing the extracorporeal blood flow.
If severe desaturation occurs during the apnea test, temporarily increase SGF/FsO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> before repeating the test.
If instability persists during the apnea test (e.g., SpO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> < 85%, unstable arrhythmia/hypotension) consider an alternative test.
If the patient is stable, assess blood gas analysis to verify that the apnea test has been completed successfully.
Adapt sampling site(s) to ECMO configuration (e.g., if > 1 sample, all should be consistent with pH/PaCO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> requirements).
On VV ECMO, take the sample on the patient using standard practice.
On VA with no native cardiac function, take the sample on the circuit after the membrane lung (ML).
On VA or V-AV ECMO) with no native cardiac function, take the sample simultaneously from the patient at the right upper limb arterial site and on the circuit after the ML.
If the patient is a potential organ donor after the apnea test:
Resume baseline settings for mechanical ventilation and ECLS to optimize end-organ oxygen delivery.
If the patient is not considered for organ donation after declaration of death:
Interrupt ECLS clamping drainage and return limbs, interrupting SGF and stopping the ECLS pump.
Circulatory Criteria for Determination of Death
Clamp drainage and return lines.
Stop the ECMO pump and set sweep gas flow to zero.
If the patient is a potential organ donor and normothermic regional perfusion is a possibility, consider these prior to withdrawal of life saving measures.
Insert an A-V bridge allowing for recirculation into the ECMO circuit, allowing for the circuit to be used after determination of death.
Flush the cannulas to ensure patency.
Wait for asystole and assess for lack of spontaneous recovery of cardiac activity as required by local regulation and institutional policy.
If the patient is a potential organ donor and normothermic regional perfusion will be performed:
Implement a strategy to regionalize extracorporeal blood flow according to the mode of ECMO.
If in VA configuration: restart ECLS.
If in V-AV configuration: restart ECLS in VA configuration, keeping venous return line clamped.
If in VV configuration:
Insert an arterial cannula.
Disconnect the return line of the circuit.
Connect the return line to the arterial cannula and restart ECLS in VA configuration, keeping the venous return cannula clamped.
Suggested Readings
Bein T, MÃ¼ller T, Citerio G. Determination of brain death under extracorporeal life support. Intensive Care Med. 2019;45(3):364-366. doi:10.1007/s00134-018-05510-z

Cho SM, Hwang J, Chiarini G, et al. Neurological monitoring and management for adult extracorporeal membrane oxygenation patients: Extracorporeal Life Support Organization consensus guidelines [published correction appears in Crit Care. 2024 Oct 7;28(1):327. doi: 10.1186/s13054-024-05107-7.]. Crit Care. 2024;28(1):296. Published 2024 Sep 6. doi:10.1186/s13054-024-05082-z
Greer DM, Shemie SD, Lewis A, et al. Determination of Brain Death/Death by Neurologic Criteria: The World Brain Death Project. JAMA. 2020;324(11):1078-1097. doi:10.1001/jama.2020.11586

Jochmans I, Hessheimer AJ, Neyrinck AP, et al. Consensus statement on normothermic regional perfusion in donation after circulatory death: Report from the European Society for Organ Transplantation's Transplant Learning Journey. Transpl Int. 2021;34(11):2019-2030. doi:10.1111/tri.13951

Meadows C, Toolan M, Slack A, et al. Diagnosis of death using neurological criteria in adult patients on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation: Development of UK guidance. J Intensive Care Soc. 2020;21(1):28-32. doi:10.1177/1751143719832170

title: Drop in Platelet Count
content: Use this checklist to guide the evaluation and management of a drop in platelet count, particularly in the context of unfractionated heparin (UFH) anticoagulation, to assess the likelihood of Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT).
keywords: Platelet count; anticoagulation; UFH; Unfractionated Heparin; Thrombin Inhibitors; Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia; HIT; PF4 Antibodies; Bleeding; Coagulants

items.label: With UFH as Anticoagulant
Check for HIT
4 T Score and/or HEP score
PF4 antibodies
Intermediate or High Probability of HIT
Check according to scores
Concomitant clotting (e.g., membrane), thromboembolism
PF4 antibodies positive
Change anticoagulation to direct thrombin inhibitor. Refer to argatroban, bivalirudin, and the comparison of anticoagulants table under Anticoagulants
Refer to Management of Bleeding.
Order confirmatory functional test for HIT II to prove diagnosis, as PF4 antibodies may be falsely positive.
Low Probability of HIT
Check according to scores
PF4 antibodies negative
Maintain UFH, adjust dose according to bleeding status.
Refer to Management of Bleeding.
Search for alternative causes for thrombocytopenia
Drugs, consumptive coagulopathy (check for signs of membrane clotting!), virus infection (e.g., CMV), etc.

title: Switch from CPB to VA ECMO
content: Use this checklist when you need to switch from Cardiopulmonary Bypass (CPB) to VA ECMO. This is designed to initiate postcardiotomy ECMO in a patient that cannot wean from cardiopulmonary bypass after a cardiothoracic intervention.
keywords: CPB;  ECMO; Procedure; Central CPB; Peripheral CPB; Central VA ECMO; Peripheral VA ECMO; VA ECMO; switch; switch mode

items.label: Switching from central CPB to central VA ECMO OR from peripheral CPB to peripheral VA ECMO
Identify the roles and responsibilities with ECLS team members.
Bring the ECMO system and circuit of choice to the operating room.
Assemble and prime the ECMO system of choice.
OR
Use the first expiring pre-assembled and/or primed circuit available (according to Institution protocol).
Connect the ECMO gas blender to the gas source.
Connect the ECMO membrane lung (ML) to the Heater unit/Heater-Cooler unit and normalize the temperature according to the patient's needs.
Prepare the required straight connectors for drainage and return line, according to cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) and ECMO circuit tubing sizes.
Possible configuration for the adults, small adults, and older (larger) children:
Â½ - â…œ  connector for venous line if a Â½ venous line was used during the CPB.
â…œ - â…œ connector for venous line if a â…œ venous line was used during.
â…œ - â…œ connector for arterial line.
Possible configuration for pediatric patients:
â…œ - Â¼ connector for venous line if a â…œ venous line was used during the CPB.
Â¼ - Â¼ connector for arterial line.
Possible configuration for infants:
Â¼ - Â¼ connectors for venous and arterial lines.
Possible configuration for neonates:
Â¼ - Â¼ connector for venous line.
3/16 - Â¼ connector for arterial line.
Consider pre-oxygenating the patient increasing FsO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> to 100% to compensate for the temporary pump stop.
Place the sterile portion of the ECMO lines in the sterile field keeping two clamps on the non-sterile portions.
Clamp the drainage/return ECMO lines where required according to desired tubing length and cut as needed.
Insert the required straight connectors on the drainage/return ECMO lines.
The lead surgeon asks the perfusionist for a CPB pump STOP.
The perfusionist stops the CPB pump and verbally confirms.
Clamp the venous and arterial CPB lines close to the cannula.
Place another clamp at 10-15 cm and cut between the two clamps.
Connect the drainage/return ECMO lines using an air-free technique.
Verify that no air is present.
Unclamp the ECMO lines and ask the perfusionist to START the ECMO pump.
Remove the clamp on the ECMO drainage line, start the ECMO pump and when safe, remove the clamp on the return side and Confirm ECMO ON.
Restart the Sweep Gas Flow.
Verify that the target extracorporeal blood flow (EBF) is achieved.
Adjust the ECMO gas blender settings as necessary.
Adjust the Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit water temperature as necessary.
Consider processing the blood inside the CPB circuit through a cell saver device to conserve blood loss.
DO NOT reverse anticoagulation.
Carefully monitor ACT without administering an additional dose until in range for ECMO (according to Institutional protocol).
Switch to the anticoagulation management/monitoring strategy adapted to the patient's characteristics and according to Institutional protocol.
Dress the insertion sites and adjust the tubing to meet the desired configuration.
When ready, move the patient to the ICU or desired location.
Switching from central CPB to peripheral VA ECMO
Identify the roles and responsibilities with ECLS team members.
Bring ECMO system and circuit of choice to the operating room.
Assemble and prime the ECMO system of choice.
OR
Use the first expiring pre-assembled/primed circuit available, according to Institution protocol.
Connect the ECMO gas blender to the gas source.
Connect the ECMO ML to the Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit and normalize the temperature according to the patient's needs.
Prepare the required straight connectors for drainage and return line, according to CPB and  ECMO circuit tubing sizes.
Possible configuration for the adult/small adult/older (larger) children:
Â½ - â…œ connector for venous line if a Â½ venous line was used during the CPB
OR
â…œ - â…œ connector for venous line if a â…œ venous line was used during.
â…œ - â…œ connector for arterial line.
Possible configuration for pediatric patients:
â…œ - Â¼ connector for venous line if a â…œ venous line was used during the CPB.
Â¼ - Â¼ connector for arterial line.
Possible configuration for infants:
Â¼ - Â¼ connectors for venous and arterial lines.
Possible configuration for neonates:
Â¼ - Â¼ connector for venous line.
3/16 - Â¼ connector for arterial line.
Place the sterile portion of the ECMO lines in the sterile field keeping two clamps on the non-sterile portions.
Clamp the drainage/return ECMO lines where required according to desired tubing length and cut as needed.
Insert the required straight connectors on the drainage/return ECMO lines.

Select the cannulae according to the patient's characteristics, expected insertion sites, and target extracorporeal blood flow (EBF). Refer to the Cannulas for additional information and specifications.
Refer to Cannulas
Bring the cannulas to the sterile field.
Expose the target insertion sites, providing antiseptic solution (according to Institution protocol).
Insert the drainage and return cannulas.
Consider inserting a distal perfusion cannula and connect it to the return cannula.
Once ready, connect the ECMO circuit to the peripheral cannulas using an air-free technique.
Verify that no air is present in the circuit.
Gradually start ECMO flow and sweep gas flow and gradually wean from CPB, providing consistent oxygen delivery throughout the procedure.
Verify that target EBF is achieved.
Adjust ECMO gas blender settings as necessary.
Adjust Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit water temperature as necessary.
Once able to provide full ECMO EBF, clamp CPB lines and stop the pump.
Carefully remove CPB cannulas and repair the insertion sites as needed.
Consider processing the blood inside the CPB circuit through a cell saver device to conserve blood loss.
DO NOT reverse anticoagulation.
Carefully monitor ACT without administering an additional dose until within range for ECMO (according to Institutional protocol).
Switch to the anticoagulation management/monitoring strategy adapted to patient's characteristics (according to Institutional protocol).
Dress the insertion sites and adjust the tubing to meet the desired configuration.
When ready, move the patient to the ICU or desired location.

title: Switch from VA ECMO to CPB
content: Use this checklist when you need to switch from VA ECMO to Cardiopulmonary Bypass (CPB). This procedure is required to initiate a cardiothoracic intervention requiring conventional CPB in a patient on VA ECMO.
keywords: CPB; ECMO; Procedure; Central CPB; Peripheral CPB; Central VA ECMO; Peripheral VA ECMO; VA ECMO; switch; switch mode

items.label: Switching from central VA ECMO to central CPB OR from peripheral VA ECMO to peripheral CPB
Identify the roles and responsibilities with ECLS team members.
Bring a CPB system and circuit of choice to the operating room.
Assemble and prime the CPB system of choice
OR
Use the first expiring pre-assembled/primed circuit available (according to Institution protocol).
Connect the CPB gas blender to the gas source.
Connect the CPB membrane lung to the Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit and normalize the temperature according to the patient's needs.
Prepare the required straight connectors for drainage and return line, according to CPB and ECMO circuit tubing sizes.
Possible configuration for the adult/small adult/older (larger) children:
â…œ - â…œ connectors for venous and arterial lines.
Possible configuration for pediatric patients:
Â¼ - Â¼ connector for venous and arterial lines.
Possible configuration for infants and neonates:
Â¼ - Â¼ connectors for venous and arterial lines.
Possible configuration for neonates:
Â¼ - Â¼ connector for venous line.

Prepare the ECMO cannulas and the distal portion of the ECMO tubings to be introduced to the sterile field, providing antiseptic solution to the incision area and cannulas/tubings (according to Institution protocol).
Introduce the sterile portion of the CPB lines to the sterile field, keeping two clamps on the non-sterile portions.
Clamp the drainage/return CPB lines according to the desired tubing length and cut.
Insert the required straight connectors on the drainage/return CPB lines.
Continue the ACT monitoring and anticoagulation management strategy according to the Institution protocol for CPB throughout the procedure.
Once ACT > 400", the leading surgeon will typically ask the perfusionist to STOP the ECMO pump.
The perfusionist stops the ECMO pump and verbally confirms.
Place clamps on the drainage and return ECMO lines close to the cannulas. Put another clamp on both sides at 10/15 cm and cut between the two clamps.
Connect the drainage/return ECMO lines using an air-free technique.
Verify that no air is present in the circuit.
Unclamp the CPB lines and ask the perfusionist to START the CPB pump.
The perfusionist removes the clamp on the CPB drainage line, starts the CPB centrifugal pump and when safe, removes the clamp on return side and confirms ON BYPASS.
OR
Remove the clamp on the return side and start the CPB roller pump, release the clamp on the drainage line and confirm ON BYPASS.
Restart the sweep gas flow.
Verify that the target extracorporeal blood flow is achieved.
Adjust the CPB gas blender settings as necessary.
Adjust the HCU water temperature as necessary to reach target temperature according to the patient and the procedure.
Consider processing the blood inside the CPB circuit through a cell saver device to conserve blood loss.
Consider connecting the drainage and return line of the CPB circuit through a straight connector to create a loop.
Keep the ECMO circuit running to be used at the end of CPB, if possible and desired.
If the circuit is retained, reduce the sweep gas flow to 0 and disconnect the gas line from the ML gas inlet.
At the end of the procedure, if is ECMO still required:
Gradually start ECMO flow and sweep gas flow.
Gradually wean from CPB to provide consistent expected oxygen delivery throughout the procedure.
Verify that the target extracorporeal blood flow is achieved.
Adjust the ECMO gas blender settings as necessary.
Adjust the Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit water temperature as necessary.
Once able to provide full ECMO extracorporeal blood flow, clamp the CPB lines and stop the pump.
Carefully remove the CPB cannulas and repair the insertion sites as needed.
Consider processing the blood inside the CPB circuit through a cell saver device to conserve blood loss.
DO NOT reverse anticoagulation.
Carefully monitor ACT without administering an additional dose until in range for ECMO (according to Institutional protocol).
Switch to the anticoagulation management/monitoring strategy adapted to patient's characteristics (according to Institutional protocol).
Dress the insertion sites and adjust the tubing according to the desired configuration.
Once ready, move the patient to the ICU or alternative location, as required.
At the end of the procedure, if ECMO is NOT required:
Wean from CPB.
Proceed with anticoagulation reversal, according to Institutional protocol.
Remove the CPB cannulas, repairing insertion points as needed.
Consider processing the blood inside the CPB and ECMO circuit through a cell saver device to conserve blood loss.
Switching from peripheral VA ECMO to central CPB
Identify the roles & responsibilities with ECLS team members.
Bring a CPB system and circuit of choice to the operating room.
Assemble and prime the CPB system of choice OR
Use the first expiring pre-assembled/primed circuit available (according to Institution protocol).
Connect the CPB gas blender to the gas source.
Connect the CPB membrane lung to the Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit and normalize the temperature according to the patient's needs.
Prepare the required straight connectors for drainage and return line, according to CPB and ECMO circuit tubing sizes.
Possible configuration for the adult/small adult/older (larger) children:
Â½ - â…œ connector for venous line if a Â½ venous line was used during the CPB
OR
â…œ - â…œ connector for venous line if a â…œ venous line was used during CPB.
â…œ - â…œ connector for arterial line.
Possible configuration for pediatric patients:
â…œ - Â¼ connector for venous line if a â…œ venous line was used during the CPB.
Â¼ - Â¼ connector for arterial line.
Possible configuration for infants:
Â¼ - Â¼ connectors for venous and arterial lines.
Possible configuration for neonates:
Â¼ - Â¼ connector for venous line.
3/16 - Â¼ connector for arterial line.
Introduce the sterile portion of the CPB lines on the sterile field keeping two clamps on the non-sterile portions.
Clamp the drainage/return CPB lines according to the desired tubing length and cut.
Insert the required straight connectors on the drainage/return CPB lines.
Proceed to the ACT monitoring and anticoagulation management strategy according to the Institution protocol for CPB.
As ACT > 300", proceed to CPB cannulation according to the planned procedure and the patient's characteristics.
As ACT > 400", connect the CPB circuit lines to the venous and arterial cannulae using an air-free technique.
Verify that no air is present in the CPB circuit.
Unclamp the CPB lines and ask the perfusionist to START the CPB pump.
The perfusionist removes the clamp on the CPB drainage line.
The perfusionist starts the CPB centrifugal pump and when safe, removes the clamp on the return side.
Verbally confirm CPB PUMP ON OR
The perfusionist removes the clamp on the return side and starts the CPB roller pump, releases the clamp on the drainage line and confirms CPB PUMP ON.
Increase CPB extracorporeal blood flow and sweep gas flow.
Gradually wean from ECMO, to provide consistent expected oxygen delivery throughout the procedure.
Clamp the venous and arterial ECMO lines close to the cannulas.
Stop the ECMO pump.
Place another clamp on both the venous and arterial lines at 10/15 cm.
Cut between each of the two clamps.
Flush the ECMO cannulas and distal perfusion catheter, then clamp.
Consider keeping the ECMO circuit running by inserting an A-V bridge connecting the drainage and return line of the ECMO circuit through Y connectors.
If so, go to zero sweep gas flow and disconnect the gas line from the ML gas inlet.
Reconnect the drainage and return ECMO lines to the ECMO cannulas using an air-free technique.
When ready, proceed with aortic cross clamping and administration of cardioplegic drugs.
Verify that target extracorporeal blood flow is achieved.
Adjust CPB gas blender settings as necessary.
Adjust the Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit water temperature as necessary to reach target temperature.
At the end of the procedure, if ECMO is still required:
Gradually start ECMO flow and sweep gas flow and gradually wean from CPB, to provide consistent expected oxygen delivery.
Verify that the target extracorporeal blood flow is achieved.
Adjust ECMO gas blender settings as necessary.
Adjust the Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit water temperature as necessary.
Once able to provide full extracorporeal blood flow on ECMO, clamp CPB lines and stop the CPB pump.
Carefully remove CPB cannulas and repair the insertion sites as needed.
Consider processing the blood inside the CPB and ECMO circuit through a cell saver device to conserve blood loss.
DO NOT reverse anticoagulation.
Carefully monitor ACT without administering an additional dose until in range for ECMO (according to Institutional protocol).
Switch to the anticoagulation management/monitoring strategy adapted to patient's characteristics (according to Institutional protocol).
Dress the insertion sites and adjust the tubing according to Institution protocol.
Once ready, move the patient to the ICU or alternative location, as required.
At the end of the procedure, if ECMO is NOT required:
Wean from CPB.
Proceed with anticoagulation reversal, according to Institutional protocol.
Remove the CPB and ECMO cannulas, repairing as needed.
Consider processing the blood inside the CPB and ECMO circuit through a cell saver device.

title: Switch from VV ECMO to CPB
content: Use this checklist when you need to switch from VV ECMO to Cardiopulmonary Bypass (CPB). This procedure is required to initiate a cardiothoracic intervention requiring conventional CPB in a patient on VV ECMO.
keywords: CPB; ECMO; Procedure; Central CPB; Peripheral CPB; Central VA ECMO; Peripheral VA ECMO; VA ECMO; switch; switch mode

items.label: Switching from peripheral VV ECMO to central OR peripheral CPB
Identify the roles and responsibilities with ECLS team members.
Assemble and prime the CPB system of choice
OR
Use the first expiring pre-assembled/primed circuit available (according to Institution protocol).
Connect the CPB gas blender to the gas source.
Connect the CPB membrane lung to the Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit and normalize temperature according to the patient's temperature.
Consider pre-oxygenating the patient increasing FsO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> to 100%, to compensate for the temporary pump stop.
Introduce the sterile portion of the CPB lines to the sterile field, keeping two clamps on the non-sterile portions.
Clamp the drainage/return CPB lines according to the desired tubing length and cut.
Insert the required straight connectors on the drainage/return CPB lines (if not included in the cannulas).
Continue ACT monitoring and anticoagulation management strategy according to the Institution protocol for CPB throughout the procedure.
As ACT > 300", proceed to CPB cannulation according to the planned procedure and the patient's characteristics.
As ACT > 400", connect the CPB circuit lines to the venous and arterial cannulae using an air free technique.
Verify that no air is present in the CPB circuit.
Unclamp the CPB lines and ask the perfusionist to START the CPB pump.
The perfusionist removes the clamp on the CPB drainage line.
The perfusionist starts the CPB centrifugal pump and when safe, removes the clamp on the return side.
The perfusionist verbally confirms CPB PUMP ON
OR
Removes the clamp on the return side and starts the CPB roller pump, releases the clamp on the drainage line and verbally confirms CPB PUMP ON.
Support the patient with CPB as required until ready for aortic cross clamping and administration of cardioplegic drugs.
As full bypass is initiated, start CPB sweep gas flow (SGF).
Stop ECMO SGF.
Decrease ECMO blood flow to the minimum safe level according to the circuit size and anticoagulation, maintaining the circuit function,
OR
Decrease ECMO SGF.
Adjust the CPB gas blender settings as necessary.
Adjust the Heater Unit/Heater-Cooler Unit water temperature as necessary to reach the target temperature according to the patient and the procedure.
Consider processing the blood inside the CPB and ECMO circuit through a cell saver device to conserve blood loss.
Consider keeping the ECMO circuit running by inserting an A-V bridge connecting the drainage and return line of the ECMO circuit through Y connectors.
If so, go to zero SGF and disconnect the gas line from the ML gas inlet.
At the end of the procedure:
Wean from CPB, gradually increasing ECMO extracorporeal blood flow and SGF to provide the required respiratory support, according to the patient's needs.
DO NOT reverse anticoagulation.
Carefully monitor ACT without administering additional dose until in range for ECMO (according to Institutional protocol).
Switch to the anticoagulation management/monitoring strategy adapted to patient's characteristics (according to Institutional protocol).
Remove the CPB cannulas, repairing insertion sites as needed.
Consider processing the blood inside the CPB and ECMO circuit through a cell saver device to conserve blood loss.
Once ready, move the patient to the ICU or alternative location, as desired.

title: Managing Gas Exchange on ECMO
content: Use these checklists to manage gas exchange in patients on ECMO, with specific considerations for both VA and VV configurations.
keywords: Gas; Exchange; Management; ECMO; VA ECMO; VV ECMO; Gas exchange; Gas exchange management

items.label: VA ECMO
VV ECMO
Suggested Readings

title: VA ECMO
content: Use this checklist to manage gas exchange in patients on VA ECMO configurations.
keywords: Gas; Exchange; Configurations;

items.label: Oxygenation
Stabilize the patient (6-12 hours).

Assess oxygen delivery/oxygen consumption (VO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) â‰¥ 3:1, mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) â‰¥65-70% and oxygen saturation of arterial blood (SaO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) around 90%.
If NO, increase blood flow and optimize hemoglobin (Hb) to 12-14 g/dL.
If YES, continue to the next step.
Achieve pulse pressure â‰¥10-15 mmHg.
If NO (non-pulsatile flow), unload the left ventricle (LV) by decreasing blood flow.
If YES, continue to the next step.

Note: when the heart begins to recoverâ€”increased pulse pressure and decreased blood flowâ€”titrate down the flow to maintain a venous saturation of >70%. When the heart function is adequate, conduct a trial off bypass.
Titrate fraction of delivered oxygen (FsO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>), which is the fraction of O<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> in the SGF.
Target slight hypoxemia (PaO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> ~150 mmHg) after the membrane lung.
Arterial return saturation (S<sub class="math-sub">post</sub>O<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) should be close to 100%.
PO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> in arterial return (P<sub class="math-sub">post</sub>O<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) should be >2-5 times the FsO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>.
* Manage the patient based on continuous venous and arterial saturation monitoring. Calculate the variables if oxygen supply seems excessive or inadequate
Carbon dioxide (CO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) removal
For adults, set sweep gas flow (SGF) between ~50-100% of the ECMO blood flow, but not less than 500 mL.
For neonates and pediatrics, set SGF between ~50-100% of the ECMO blood flow.
For patients of all ages, check blood gas analysis within five minutes to prevent hypocapnia.
Adjust ventilator rest settings.
Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) to achieve an adequate PaO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> in the right arm.
Avoid hyperoxemia.
If there is heart and lung participation, adjust the ventilatory settings to regulate partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) (within lung protection).
Measure partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) at the right upper limb and post-membrane lung if the heart is ejecting.
If ~35-45 mmH<sub class="math-sub">2</sub>O, continue
If <35 mmH<sub class="math-sub">2</sub>O, decrease (â†“) sweep flow
If >45 mmH<sub class="math-sub">2</sub>O, increase (â†‘) sweep flow
Note: If PCO2 â‰¥ 80-90 mmH2O, avoid abruptly dropping the PCO2 (which is associated with neurological injury). Hypercapnia may be gradually controlled.

title: VV ECMO
content: Use this checklist to manage gas exchange in patients on VV ECMO configurations.
keywords: Gas; Exchange; Configurations;

items.label: Oxygenation
If the native lung is not working, set the ECMO flow to 60-80% of the measured cardiac output:
Stabilize the patient (6-12 hours).
Assess DO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>/VO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> >3:1, SaO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> >85-90%.
If YES, no changes are necessary.
If NO, optimize hemoglobin (Hb) to between 12-14 g/dL.
Note: There is a tradeoff of risk between transfusion and increasing circuit flow which favors transfusion of red blood cells (RBCs). Membrane lungs function optimally at a normal hematocrit.
If delivered oxygen (DO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) is still inadequate, change the drainage cannula to a larger size (or adding additional venous drainage access) and increase blood flow.
Avoid hypoxemia (PaO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> < 60 mmHg).
Improvement in lung function?
If YES, continue to next step.

Note: As soon as there is lung recovery (defined as increased DO2 by the native lung and a decreased need for a DO2 by the ECMO circuit) requiring less blood flow or allowing a lower level of hemoglobin, start VV ECMO weaning.

If NO, consider high O<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> consumption (fever, sepsis, activity) or recirculation (high SvO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> and SaO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>).
Note: If recirculation is suspected:
Refer to the Recirculation calculator
Check the distance between the drainage and return cannulas (>8-10 cm, 15 is better)
If DLC, check its position
Look for tension PTX, cardiac tamponade or other cause impairing venous return
Verify that EBF is not excessive in relation to cannula size
Refer to Cannulas
* Manage the patient based on continuous venous and arterial saturation monitoring.
Carbon dioxide (CO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>) removal
Consider all the circuit management based on oxygenation.
The amount of CO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> exchanged per minute is essentially the same as the amount of oxygen (120 cc/min/m<sup class="math-sup">2</sup> for adults).

CO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> is much more soluble and diffusible in blood than O<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>, so CO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> clearance will exceed oxygenation in any circumstance.
Note: If CO2 clearance is the only or the major goal, much lower blood flow can be used, and hemoglobin concentration is not important.
Sweep gas is adjusted to maintain the desired systemic partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>).
Be advised: One phenomenon unique to ECMO is the effect of water accumulation on the gas side of the membrane lung. This is the only circumstance in which CO2 clearance is less than oxygenation.

title: Membrane Lung Failure
keywords: Membrane; Lung; Membrane Lung; Membrane Lung Failure; Gas Transfer; Gas Supply Interruption

items.label: Exclude a Gas Supply Interruption
Go to the Gas Supply Interruption checklist. Once a gas supply interruption is ruled out, return to and complete this checklist.
Evaluate the Membrane Lung (ML) Pressures and Blood Flow
Assess pre-membrane lung pressure (P<sub class="math-sub">PRE-ML</sub><HtmlSpacer></HtmlSpacer>)
Assess post-membrane lung pressure (P<sub class="math-sub">POST-ML</sub><HtmlSpacer></HtmlSpacer>)
Assess extracorporeal blood flow (EBF)
Calculate pressure drop or delta P Î”P = PPRE-ML - PPOST-ML
Open Notes to record the value.
Calculate membrane lung resistances (MLR) MLR = Î”P/EBF
Open Notes to record the value.
Check your values against the standard pressures for the device, listed in the Membrane Lung equipment section.
Go to Membrane Lung
Values are excessive compared to standard pressures
There are progressive or acute increases in Î”P and MLR compared to the previous evaluation
There is a progressive increase in rotations per minute (RPMs) to maintain target EBF
If any boxes are checked, ML dysfunction or failure is likely.
Consider ML or circuit exchange
Consider coming oï¬€ ECMO emergently if preferable for the patient
Refer to Circuit Change (Emergent and Elective)
Refer to Coming Off ECMO Emergently
If none of the boxes are checked, continue to the next step: Evaluate ML Gas Transfer Effectiveness.
Evaluate ML Gas Transfer Effectiveness
Flush the gas line
Carefully increase the sweep gas flow (SGF) for 5-10 s to displace condensation while monitoring EtCO<sub class="math-sub">2</sub> and the patient's hemodynamics
ML recruitment checklist
Maximize SGF and O<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> fraction in the sweep gas flow (FsO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub>)
Sample the blood before and after the ML to assess the O<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> uptake
Is there a decreased O<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> uptake?
Is the P<sub class="math-sub">POST-ML</sub><HtmlSpacer></HtmlSpacer> O<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> < 200 mmHg ?
Is the Vâ€™O<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> < 100-150 mL/min?
Go to Oxygen Transfer calculator
Assess CO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> removal
Has it decreased?
Is the P<sub class="math-sub">POST-ML</sub><HtmlSpacer></HtmlSpacer> CO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> > 40 mmHg?

Is the P<sub class="math-sub">PRE-ML</sub><HtmlSpacer></HtmlSpacer> CO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> â€“ P<sub class="math-sub">POST-ML</sub><HtmlSpacer></HtmlSpacer> CO<sub class="math-sub mr-pad">2</sub> < 10 mmHg?
If at least one YES without an alternative explanation, excluding a gas supply interruption, ML dysfunction or failure is likely.
Consider performing a circuit change or coming off ECMO if itâ€™s preferable for the patient.
Refer to Circuit Component Changes
Refer to Coming Off ECMO
If NO, continue to the next step: Assess the Patientâ€™s Hematologic Profile
Assess the Patient's Hematologic Profile
Evaluate hemolysis:
Free hemoglobin (fHb)
LDH
Is the LDH elevated?
Is the plasma fHb > 50 mg/dL?
If the answer is YES to either without an alternative explanation, consider ML or circuit change.
Evaluate coagulation:
PLTs
INR
aPTT
D-dimer
Fibrinogen
Viscoelastic testing (VET)
Are there signs of coagulopathy?
Have INR and aPTT increased?
Have the PLTs decreased?
Has the D-dimer increased?
Has Fibrinogen decreased?
Are TEG or ROTEM suggesting signs of consumptive coagulopathy?
If the answer is YES for more than one of the questions above without an alternative explanation, ML dysfunction or failure is likely.
Consider performing a circuit change or coming off ECMO if itâ€™s preferable for the patient.
Refer to Circuit Component Changes
Refer to Coming Off ECMO
If the answer is NO for the above questions, ML dysfunction or failure is unlikely.
Closely monitor the patient and consider alternative cause(s)

title: Proning on ECMO
keywords: Proning; ECMO;  Procedure; Prone position; Prone; Supine; Supine position; Turning patients; ECMO patients; Turning ECMO patients

items.label: Patient
Consider the risks and benefits of turning a patient on ECMO to the prone position.
Assess the patient for any relative or absolute contraindications to prone positioning.
Contraindications include:
Pregnancy
Suspected raised intracranial pressure
Spinal instability
Recent sternotomy
Facial surgery
Severe haemodynamic instability
Open abdomen
Trauma with unstable fractures
Ensure that there is adequate sedation and full neuromuscular blockade.
Clear the range of motion of the cervical spine and shoulders to identify any necessary positional alternations and to avoid musculoskeletal or neurological injuries.
Apply protective dressings to pressure areas to prevent pressure injury.
Protect eyes with protective covers or eye pads.
Check that all tubes, lines, and drains are properly secured.
ECMO
Perform a circuit check to ensure that all connections are tightened and cannulas are secured with sutures and securement straps and/or adhesive tapes.
If necessary, relocate the ECMO console and power and gas supply to facilitate the position change.
Equipment
Ensure that continuous monitoring equipment (e.g., blood pressure, oxygen saturation, etc.) is set up and functioning.
Reposition the electrocardiogram (EKG) leads to the patient's back.
Position the circuit tubing, lines, and drains above the waist towards the head of the bed, and those below the waist towards the foot of the bed.
Ensure the availability of emergency equipment and a crash cart at the bedside.
Team
Organize an adequate number of trained staff for the position change (at least six staff members).
Discuss and confirm the roles of each member.
Assign one staff member to take care of the ECMO console and tubing.
Assign another staff member to manage the airway, lines, and cannula in the neck region.
Establish the time frame for supine positioning and specific timing of the supining procedure.
Define clinical parameters for escalation of any concerns, including interruption of prone positioning and clinical indications of emergency de-proning.
These parameters should be agreed to by all team members prior to assessing and proning the patient so that all staff changes have clear expectations.
Establish criteria to pause and reassess proning and the escalation pathway for possible adverse events and complications such as:
Hemodynamic instability and/or Desaturation
Lower ECMO flow
Accidental extubation, decannulation, or line displacement
Bleeding from ECMO cannula sites
Machine malfunction
Update Patient's Family
Provide an update to the patientâ€™s family of the patient's condition and communicate the risks and benefits of prone positioning.
Turning an ECMO Patient
Complete this checklist if you are turning an ECMO patient from the prone position to a supine position.
Team members should always follow the team leaderâ€™s command.
Closely monitor the ECMO blood flow and line pressures during a position change.
Ensure patient safety during position change:
One staff member at the head end guides the procedure, and holds the artificial airway and the jugular ECMO cannula, if present.
One staff member at the feet end holds the ECMO cannula and tubing while monitoring ECMO parameters.
At least two staff members standing on each side of the bed to help turn the patient using the double-sheets technique.
Avoid placing any tension on the ECMO tubing during turning.
Monitor the patientâ€™s physiological parameters for changes and tolerance to the prone position.
During Prone Positioning
Complete this checklist if the ECMO patient is in a prone position.
Continuously monitor the patientâ€™s vitals and response to prone therapy.
Closely monitor the ECMO blood flow and line pressures for any adjustments that may be necessary.
Free breasts, abdomen, and genitals from any pressure.
For obese patients, position the abdomen carefully to avoid an increase in intra-abdominal pressure and use a reverse Trendelenburg position, if possible.
Reposition the patient's head and upper limbs at regular intervals according to institutional policy.
Protect body areas with dedicated pillows or pressure relieving devices to prevent pressure injuries.
Turning a Patient Back to Supine Position
Complete this checklist if you are turning an ECMO patient from the prone position to a supine position.
The procedure is a reversal of the prone positioning maneuver.
Use extreme caution to avoid accidental extubation, decannulation, and patient injuries.
Check the patientsâ€™ vitals to confirm stability. Intervene immediately if vitals become unstable.
Confirm that the cannula positions have remained unchanged.
Confirm that ECMO blood flow and line pressures are within target ranges.
Evaluate the patientâ€™s response after turning them back to a supine position, and determine a plan for the next day if indicated.
Suggested Readings
De Jong A, Wrigge H, Hedenstierna G, et al. How to ventilate obese patients in the ICU. Intensive Care Med. 2020;46(12):2423-2435. doi:10.1007/s00134-020-06286-x
Bruni A, Garofalo E, Longhini F. Avoiding complications during prone position ventilation. Intensive Crit Care Nurs. 2021;66:103064. doi:10.1016/j.iccn.2021.103064
Physiotherapy and Mobilization. In: Extracorporeal Life Support - The ELSO Red Book 6th ed

title: PT/Ambulation on ECMO
keywords: PT; Ambulation; ECMO; PT AMBULATION; MOBILIZE; MOBILIZING; PHYSICAL REHABILITATION; PHYSICAL THERAPY; CARDIOPULMONARY FAILURE; TREATMENT; PROCEDURE

items.label: Patient Preparation for Ambulation
Review the patientâ€™s underlying medical condition and level of ECMO support.
Assess the level of consciousness, oxygen and ventilatory requirement, inotrope and/or vasopressor requirement, and comorbid conditions.
Determine the appropriateness, level, and frequency of physiotherapy and mobilization.
Team Preparation
Organize the appropriate staff members based on your institutional requirements for mobilization.
Discuss and confirm the roles of each member before mobilization.
Engage families in mobilization planning and its execution, establishing both daily and long-range goals.
Consider the specific precautions for different types of cannulas, device components and cannulation sites on mobilization.

items: See Instructions for Use (IFUs) if needed.

items.label: Establish criteria to pause and reassess as well as an escalation pathway for possible adverse events and complications:
Visit the PANIC! section for additional information.
Equipment Preparation
Prepare the equipment necessary for the mobilization.
Ensure the availability of emergency equipment at the bedside.
Cannulation Consideration
Identify the cannula-specific risks associated with the mobilization of different body parts.
Check that all cannulas are secured per institutional protocols, with specific consideration for the range of limb movement required for mobilization.
During Physiotherapy and Mobilization Exercise
Assign one staff member to take care of the ECMO console and tubing.

Create an individualized plan for physiotherapy and mobilization that considers the patientâ€™s condition, sedation levels, oxygen requirements, muscle power, patient cooperation, cannula sites, and team availability.
Deep Sedation:
Passive range of the motion movement of limbs
Electrical muscle stimulation
Proper limb positioning
Supine cycle ergometer
Mild to Moderate Sedation:
Sitting in reclined bed with the head and trunk upright, lift transfer to chair
Grade 0 muscle power: passive mobilization
Grade 1 â€“ 2 muscle power: active assisted exercise
Grade 3 muscle power: active exercises
Grade 4 â€“ 5 muscle power: resistive exercise
Awake:
Neck and trunk control
Sitting on the edge of the bed
Muscle strengthening using an elastic band
Closed kinetic exercises
Standing out of bed
Marching in place with or without support
Walking with assistance
Closely monitor ECMO blood flow and line pressures during activity.
Change the ventilator or ECMO settings, or both, as appropriate to meet the additional oxygen demand during ambulation.
Assess the cannula stability regularly, including during and after every position change.
Take caution to avoid malposition, kinking and dislodgement or disconnection of ECMO cannulas and tubing during mobilization.
Monitor the patientâ€™s physiological parameters for changes and tolerance during the session.
Identify the clinical parameters for pausing or discontinuing the activity.
After Physiotherapy and Mobilization Exercise
Assess the patientâ€™s tolerance for activity based on vital signs and rating of perceived exertion and intervene as necessary.
Confirm positions of the cannulas are unchanged, they remain secure, and dressing remains clean, dry, and intact.
Ensure all equipment is plugged back to the main power and gas supply after ambulation.
Perform a circuit check of the ECMO components.
Evaluate the patientâ€™s response after mobilization and determine a plan for the next day if indicated.
Suggested Readings

Abrams D, Madahar P, Eckhardt CM, et al. Early Mobilization during Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation for Cardiopulmonary Failure in Adults: Factors Associated with Intensity of Treatment. Ann Am Thorac Soc. 2022;19(1):90-98. doi:10.1513/AnnalsATS.202102-151OC
Haji JY, Mehra S, Doraiswamy P. Awake ECMO and mobilizing patients on ECMO. Indian J Thorac Cardiovasc Surg. 2021;37(Suppl 2):309-318. doi:10.1007/s12055-020-01075-z
MacLaren G, Brodie D, et al, eds. Extracorporeal Life Support: The ELSO Red Book, 6th ed. ELSO; 2022.

Ramsey S, Shehatta AL, Ramanathan K, et al. Extracorporeal Life Support Organization 2024 Guideline for Early Rehabilitation or Mobilization of Adult Patients on Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation. ASAIO J. 2025;71(3):187-199. doi:10.1097/MAT.0000000000002375
Salna M, Abrams D, Brodie D. Physical rehabilitation in the awake patient receiving extracorporeal circulatory or gas exchange support. Ann Transl Med. 2020;8(13):834. doi:10.21037/atm.2020.03.151

title: UFH Anticoagulation Monitoring and Management
content:
This checklist outlines the monitoring and management of unfractionated heparin (UFH) anticoagulation in patients on ECMO.

Anticoagulation should be monitored in the context of their individual baseline (as opposed to a laboratory baseline), overall inflammatory state â€” such as septic shock, end-organ dysfunction (liver and kidney) and platelet function as well as consideration of their unique bleeding and clotting risks.

Variability and therapeutic ranges differ between clinical sites and should be individualized.
keywords: UFH; Unfractionated Heparin; Anticoagulation; Monitoring; Management; Algorithm

items.label: ECMO Cannulation
UFH IV Bolus: 50-100 IU/kg
Consider dose according to coagulation status and bleeding risk.
UFH Monitoring
Determine activated clotting time (ACT)
Suggested range for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO): 180-200 seconds.
If prolonged, consider hypothermia, platelet function/number, and coagulation factor levels.
Note: ACT with other coagulation tests (including anti-Xa/heparin levels and aPTT) is frequently discordant.
Determine activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
Suggested therapeutic targets: 40â€“50 seconds initially, then titrated to 60â€“80 seconds depending on bleeding and/or thrombosis risk.
This test does not account for platelet function or clot strength. It evaluates clot formation based on mechanical or optical clot detection with ellagic acid.
Lower targets in VV ECMO possible:

LowAntiXa: 0.2â€“0.3 IU/mL
aPTT: 40â€“55s (ratio 1.2â€“1.6)
ModerateAntiXa: 0.3â€“0.5 IU/mL
aPTT: 50â€“70s (ratio 1.5â€“2.0)
HighAntiXa: 0.5â€“0.7 IU/mL
aPTT: 60â€“80s (ratio 1.8â€“2.4)
Note: aPTT is affected by antithrombin, factor VIII, factor XII, and fibrinogen levels. There is often discordance with anti-Xa monitoring.
Determine anti-factor Xa levels
Suggested ECMO target levels range: 0.3-0.7 IU/mL.
This test correlates better with unfractionated heparin (UFH) levels than aPTT.

Note: Anti-factor Xa does not evaluate clot formation, and it can be influenced by patient AT deficiency, hyperlipidemia, coagulation factor hemolysis with increased plasma hemoglobin/or hyperbilirubinemia.
Evaluate viscoelastic tests (e.g., TEG and ROTEM)
ROTEM: rotational thromboelastometry
TEG: thromboelastometry

These tests incorporate platelet function and assess clot strength using specific activators (e.g., tissue factor, ellagic acid, kaolin) to evaluate whole blood clot formation, and are often used for bleeding management evaluation rather than anticoagulation monitoring.
Optimize antithrombin (AT)
This is critical for heparin effectiveness.
Levels decrease during ECMO due to consumptive coagulopathy and other causes.
Note: There is no data supporting improved outcomes with supplementation in ECMO patients.
For additional information, refer to the Discrepancy between aPTT and AntiXa with UFH table.
UFH Management
UFH bolus at cannulation for ECMO
ELSO recommends:
Adults and newborns 50â€“100 U/kg.
Adjust based on pre-existing bleeding disorders:
Postsurgical ECMO (especially postcardiotomy)
Recent trauma
Type of cannulation (surgical or arterial at increased risk)
ECMO duration
Pre-ECMO coagulation abnormalities
On-ECMO aPTT >72 s, fibrinogen <2 g/L, and platelets count <38,000/mmÂ³
Continuous infusion dose
ELSO recommends:
Adults 7.5â€“20 U/kg/hr and newborns 20â€“50 U/kg/hr.
Adjust based on:
aPTT (goal: 1.5-2.5)
Anti-Xa levels (goal: 0.3-0.7 U/mL)
ACT
Viscoelastic tests
Discrepant Anticoagulation Tests
Anti-Xa levels between 0.3â€“0.7 U/mL.
aPTT <60 s, consider a hypercoagulable state.
aPTT 60-90 s, no change.
aPTT >90 s, repeat aPTT, consider fresh frozen plasma (FFP) if still high.
Anti-Xa levels <0.3 U/mL.
aPTT <60 s, increase heparin.
aPTT 60-90 s, increase heparin.
aPTT >90 s, consider factor deficiency and repletion with FFP.
Anti-Xa levels >0.7 U/mL.
aPTT <60 s, unlikely to occur; consider repeat labs.
aPTT 60-90 s, consider repeat labs or a hypercoagulable state.
aPTT >90 s, decrease heparin.
If there is a discrepancy between anticoagulation tests, please refer to the Discrepancy between aPTT and AntiXa with UFH Table under Medications.
Common problems occurring during heparin use for ECMO therapy
High heparin dose to reach target? Or target not reached?
Consider heparin resistance (>35,000 units/day)
Determine antithrombin (AT) levels
Consider repletion (desirable range in adults: 80â€“120%, there is no established baseline AT levels in children)
Evaluate other causes such as hyperfibrinogenemia or thrombocytosis
If problem remains consider changing to DTI
Decreasing platelet count (~50% or progressive).
Evaluate for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) (determine PF4 antibodies)
If Platelet Factor 4 (PF4) antibodies are positive and clinically compatible with HIT, send functional assay and switch to direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI)
In case of DIC, consider clotting in circuit and circuit exchange
In thrombocytopenia < 50,000 due to patient related problems and after exclusion of HIT, consider platelet transfusion and/or reduced anticoagulation level
Thrombosis
If clotting of membrane lung: exchange
If there is repeated clotting and/or systemic thrombosis, consider increasing heparin and search for hypercoagulable state:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)
Antiphospholipid Ab
Major bleeding
This includes:
Intracranial hemorrhage
Surgical site bleeding
Gastrointestinal and pulmonary hemorrhage
Cannulation site bleeding
Reduce or stop heparin, and keep pump blood flow high.
Local hemostasis (wounds, cannula, GI, etc.) if possible.
Check for coagulation disorders and correct.
If anti-Xa levels are above target, reduce.
If factors II, V, VII, X deficiency, replete.
If platelet deficiency (excluding HIT), consider platelet transfusion.
If DIC and hyperfibrinolysis, treat the cause and consider membrane lung change.
If acquired Von Willebrand syndrome, repletion and reduce ECMO pump speed if possible.
Note: Case reports and case series have reported successful management of bleeding of patients with ECMO with prolonged periods of no anticoagulation.
Suggested Readings
Amodeo I, Di Nardo M, Raffaeli G, Kamel S, Macchini F, Amodeo A, et al. Neonatal respiratory and cardiac ECMO in Europe. Eur J Pediatr. (2021) 180:1675â€“92.

Buchtele N, Schwameis M, Schellongowski P, et al. Prevalence and clinical impact of reduced coagulation factor XII activity in patients receiving extracorporeal membrane oxygenation. Crit Care Med. 2021;49:e1206â€“e1211.

Chegondi M, Vijayakumar N, Totapally BR. Management of Anticoagulation during Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation in Children. Pediatr Rep. 2022 Jul 11;14(3):320-332. doi: 10.3390/pediatric14030039. PMID: 35894028; PMCID: PMC9326610.
Chlebowski MM, Baltagi S, Carlson M, Levy JH, Spinella PC. Clinical controversies in anticoagulation monitoring and antithrombin supplementation for ECMO. Crit Care. 2020;24:19.
Erdoes G, Koster A, Levy JH. Viscoelastic coagulation testing: use and current limitations in perioperative decision-making. Anesthesiology. 2021;135:342â€“349.

Levy JH, Staudinger T, Steiner ME. How to manage anticoagulation during extracorporeal membrane oxygenation. Intensive Care Med. 2022 Aug;48(8):1076-1079. doi: 10.1007/s00134-022-06723-z. Epub 2022 Jun 11. PMID: 35689697; PMCID: PMC9187844.
McMichael ABV, Ryerson LM, Ratano D, et al. 2021 ELSO Adult and Pediatric Anticoagulation Guidelines. ASAIO Journal. 2022 Mar;68(3):303-310, March 2022. | DOI: 10.1097/MAT.0000000000001652
Nguyen TP, Phan XT, Nguyen TH, et al. Major bleeding in adults undergoing peripheral extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO): prognosis and predictors. Crit Care Res Pract. 2022;2022:5348835.
Price EA, Jin J, Nguyen HM, et al. Discordant aPTT and anti-Xa values and outcomes in hospitalized patients treated with intravenous unfractionated heparin. Ann Pharmacother. 2013;47:151â€“158.
Sklar MC, Sy E, Lequier L, et al. Anticoagulation practices during venovenous extracorporeal membrane oxygenation for respiratory failure: A systematic review. Ann Am Thorac Soc. 2016;13:2242â€“2250.

title: Whole Circuit Replacement
content: This checklist should be adapted to align with institutional policies, specific patient conditions, and available resources.
keywords: ECMO Circuit; Circuit Change; Circuit Replacement; Equipment; ECMO;

items.label: Identify the need for whole circuit replacement
All three checks are required, otherwise do NOT proceed with the whole circuit replacement.
Note: We do NOT recommend the replacement of a functioning circuit (e.g., due date as per IFU), as the risks associated with replacement outweigh the benefits.
A dysfunctional circuit: (at least one check)
Circuit thrombosis (minor membrane lung (ML) clotting not severely impacting with its function excluded) or unexplained coagulopathy.
Refer to Membrane Lung Failure.
Pump thrombosis
Massive air entrance
Refer to Air in Circuit
ML/pumphead rupture (if a rupture of a minor component) selectively change or isolate
A positive culture from the circuit refractory to optimize treatment/sustained by MRD/EDR/PDR organisms AND/OR evidence of microorganism growth on the ML
No weaning potential
Selective replacement of the involved component is not feasible for any reason.
Go to Component Replacement checklist
Alert/activate the ECLS and the ICU teams and assign clear roles
1 experienced intensivist and/or 1 experienced ICU nurse to support the patient
2 ECMOlogists to simultaneously work on drainage/return as sterile operators lines if elective procedure
At least 1 ECMOlogists to work on drainage/return lines as sterile operator if emergent procedure (2 operators are better, if feasible)
At least 1 ECMO specialist/perfusionist to prepare and manage the new circuit
At least 1 supporting healthcare worker
If this is an elective procedure, consider a short briefing.
Prepare the Essential Equipment
Consider also keeping an ECMO cart close to the procedure for emergencies.
Refer to the ECMO Cart checklist for more information.
Consider reading Chapters 4 and 7 of the ELSO Red Book, 6th edition for air-free connection.
Go to ELSO Red Book, 6th edition
Sterile consumables for setting up a sterile field
Sterile tubing scissors
2 sterile tubing clamps for drainage line tubing clamps
1 sterile bowl
2 sterile tubing clamps for return line
2 back-up sterile clamps
1L of crystalloid solution and  additional crystalloid solution if required for priming (no pre-primed circuit)
Primed back-up circuit on a back-up machine
OR
Primed back-up circuit on a back-up pump
2 straight connectors adapted to circuit tubing size OR cannulas
Scalpel to remove the tubing from the connector
Disinfecting solution and/or applicators for tubing preparation (per center institutional policy)
Prepare the Patient
Consider all of the following:
Supine the patient as ready for initiation.
If the patient is awake, inform him/her and/or their surrogate about the need for replacement, the procedure and potential associated risks.
If the patient is awake, consider sedation if deemed necessary.
Improve mechanical ventilation settings as ready to interrupt EBF on VV ECMO, V-AV ECMO, VP ECMO.
Improve inotropic/vasopressor support as ready to interrupt EBF on VA ECMO, V-AV ECMO, VP ECMO.
Be ready for packed red blood cell (PRBC) transfusion, if required.
Be ready to perform CPR/ACLS if/as required in case of emergency.
If the patient isn't on mechanical ventilation, be ready to manage airways in case of emergency.
Check the coagulation profile and increase anticoagulant dosing, if deemed necessary.
Proceed with Replacement
If cardiac arrest occurs during the procedure and EBF can be promptly restarted, carefully consider if adrenaline administration is advisable or could be delayed.
Sterile Operators
Disinfect the portion of the old drainage and return tubing which is going to be clamped and cut.
Allow the disinfection solution to act for enough time according to the solution which has been used.
Prepare the sterile field
Bring the sterile portion of the new circuit tubings on the field, then clamp and cut to the desired length.
If using new connectors, connect these to the drainage and return tubing.
Place two clamps approximately 15 cm (six inches) apart on both limbs of the old circuit to isolate.
Cut drainage and return lines between the clamps.
Make an air-free connection between the old and the new lines.
Double check:
Drainage with drainage line (blue markings)
Return with return line (red markings)
Remove all clamps apart from one on the return side.
Ask the ECMO specialist/perfusionist to restart the pump.
Check all connections for tightness and integrity, and secure all connections.
ECMO Specialist/Perfusionist
Note: These steps should be performed simultaneously for both roles.
If ready for clamping on the field, clamp the return line.
Go to 0 RPMs.
Clamp the drainage line.
Disconnect the gas line from the old circuit.
Connect gas line to the new circuit.
*OPTIONAL â€” If requested by sterile operators, fill the tubings after the clamps and the connectors using a line connected on the circuit.
Increase pump speed as requested by the team leader.
As the minimum RPMs are reached to prevent backflow (depending on IFUs - refer to Pumps) and remove the last clamp on the return line.
Refer to the Pump specifications.
Go back to previous RPMs settings if there are no signs of a return obstruction.
Go to Return Obstruction checklist.
Go back to previous FsOâ‚‚ settings.
Carefully increase sweep gas flow (SGF) considering enhanced ML function.
Dispose of the old circuit according to hospital protocol.
If a new ECMO machine was used, clean the one which was previously used according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Post-replacement Management
Strictly monitor the patient for signs of complications.
Adapt the ECMO settings as needed, considering the improved function of the new circuit.
Perform a full circuit assessment before leaving the patient.
Refer to the Circuit Monitoring checklist for more information.
Document the procedure in the patient's chart, including:
The reason for replacement
Time of the procedure
Circuit/connectors lot numbers
Complications encountered if any, operators
Report the procedure in the ELSO registry.
